text:
Argh. Get an excel sheet with 2 columns of 40 numbers (grades). “My my, they look correlated - let me have  a look. Let me just open Julia”. Open REPL, walk slowly to the folder,  open Pluto, new notebook - open the notebook takes like a full minute, and I’m starting to forget what I wanted to see. `using StatsPlots` - error saying “try `]instantiate`“. Turns out `]` doesn’t work in Pluto. In fact, Pkg operations don’t really work in Pluto. Instantiate has no effect. Open a new REPL, instantiate, status, resolve, no issues. `using StatsPlots` in REPL no issue. Open Pluto again, `using StatsPlots`- error saying “try `]instantiate`“. Open Excel and do the work I wanted to do there.
For all it’s beauty, Julia really isn’t very nice for quick stuff.

text: Agreed, but in that situation, my instinct would be to copy-paste the rows into the REPL and parse them using UnicodePlots

elements.text: Agreed, but in that situation, my instinct would be to copy-paste the rows into the REPL and parse them using UnicodePlots

text: You can also pipe them directly into a DataFrame with ExcelFiles.jl <https://github.com/queryverse/ExcelFiles.jl>

elements.text: You can also pipe them directly into a DataFrame with ExcelFiles.jl

text:
Yeah, second the copy-paste-into-REPL approach.

Also, not sure which OS you’re on but rather than slowly `cd` ing to the file you want to load, `Command-option-c` on mac to copy the full file path of  the currently-highlighted file in the finder has been a life-changer for me

elements.text:

on mac to copy the full file path of  the currently-highlighted file in the finder has been a life-changer for me

text: why would you switch from excel to julia if you want to plot data you have in excel?

elements.text: why would you switch from excel to julia if you want to plot data you have in excel?
excel has excellent ttfp

text: because something went wrong with my excel graph so the window stayed blank :neutral_face:

elements.text: because something went wrong with my excel graph so the window stayed blank

text: that's probably because it is done plotting in under 4ms and exits gracefully afterwards

elements.text: that's probably because it is done plotting in under 4ms and exits gracefully afterwards

text: Not a julia solution, but if you use vscode the  <https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=msrvida.vscode-sanddance|SandDance> extension is good for quick plotting in the editor.

text: Also not addressing the root concern, but in actuarial work, there’s a lot of Excel work and to facilitate quick back and forth with Julia, I <https://github.com/JuliaActuary/ActuaryUtilities.jl#excel-utilities|added >`xlclip` to ActuaryUtilities.jl
